PuMA_V3¶

System requirements:¶

  1. Mac or Linux (Tested on MacOS 10.14.1+, Ubuntu 12.04+, and RHEL)

  2. gcc version 4.4.7+

  3. Conda installation (either Anaconda or Miniconda)

Installation (C++):¶

Installation of dependencies, PuMA C++ library and executables:¶

Download PuMA_V3 and unzip, then open a terminal and navigate into the “PuMA_V3” folder. If on a Mac, execute “bash” to make sure the bash shell is active. Then run:

./makeAll

The PuMA library is now installed in install/lib and the executables in install/bin.

In order to test the installation and solvers, it is recommended to run the pumaX_testing executable, found in install/bin. This will run the full suite of unit and integration tests using the pumaTest testing framework.

Note: PuMA relies on conda in order to manage the software dependencies and environment variables. The provided bash scripts for compiling and launching the software take care of activating the conda environment for you. If, however, you wanted to compile or run the software outside of these scripts, you must first execute “conda activate puma” in the terminal. For example, if one wanted to use an IDE to develop and run the software, the puma conda environment should be loaded prior to launching the IDE from a terminal, such that all the environment variables are properly set up.

Launching the PuMA GUI:¶

After running the PuMA installation (./makeAll command), the PuMA GUI can now be launched by opening a terminal, navigating into the PuMA_V3 folder, and running:

./launchGUI

The first time running this executable, the PuMA GUI will be installed, which may take a couple of minutes. Each subsequent time the command is executed, the GUI should launch without delay.

If the above instructions do not work, please reach out to either Joseph Ferguson (joseph.ferguson@stanford.edu) or Federico Semeraro (federico.semeraro@nasa.gov) for help with installation. In the email, please send details on the computer system that you are trying to install PuMA on, as well as the output of the terminal during compilation.

How to link your project to the PuMA C++ library API:¶

In the folder initproject there is a simple example project already linked to the PuMA library. For beginners, it is recommended to start copying and pasting intothe main.cpp the examples and compiling it by running “make”. Since the PuMA installation uses conda to manage the dependencies, the puma environment needs to be first loaded by running:

conda activate puma

Installation (Python):¶

PuMApy is a Python distribution of PuMA and it uses a different environment because of the extra capabilities it has (TexGen and FEniCS coupling). To install PuMApy, discard the above instructions and instead run:

./install_pumapy

The pumapy conda environment and python package are now installed. PuMApy can be loaded in any python session inside the pumapy conda environment (i.e. after running “conda activate pumapy”) by importing it as “import pumapy”.

Documentation:¶

The documentation can be accessed by opening the index file in a browser.

Recommended specs:¶

  • 8 GB of ram for small simulations (5003 or smaller)

  • 16-32 GB of ram for medium simulations (8003 range)

  • 32+ GB of ram for large simulations (above 10003)

Reporting bugs:¶

If any bugs are found, or if the software crashes for any reason, please contact any of the developers mentioned above and send the associated log file, found in the “logs” directory.

Common errors¶

Here is a list of the common errors encountered during the setup and how to solve them:

  • When running PuMApy, if an “MPI_Init_thread” error is displayed when importing pumpapy, add “export MPICH_INTERFACE_HOSTNAME=localhost” to ~/.bashrc (Linux) or ~/.bash_profile (Max).

  • If receiving the error message “Permission Denied” for any of the installation files, run “chmod +x file_name”

Contributing to PuMA:¶

Since PuMA is a free research code, any user is welcome to contribute or collaborate however they would like. If you are interested in significant development for your research goals, please contact send an email to Joseph Ferguson and Federico Semeraro (emails below)

Authors:¶

Maintainer: Federico Semeraro federico.semeraro@nasa.gov
